what: Using R packages for categorical data modeling: a workflow
title: Workflow
text: empirical studies, goodness--fit analysis used jointly statistical tools, variable screening/selection model diagnostics, model-building refining process. section, discuss follow workflow following diagram carry statistical modeling categorical data. also discuss use \(\textbf{SurrogateRsq}\) package existing R packages implement workflow. Liu et al. (2023)’s method requires full model, researchers practitioners can also follow process Figure initiate full model facilitate goodness--fit analysis. illustration workflow modeling categorical data \(\texttt{Step-0}\), can use AIC/BIC/LASSO variable selection methods deemed appropriate trim prune set explanatory variables ``manageable’’ size (e.g., less 20). goal eliminate irrelevant variables researchers can better investigate model structure assessment. variable selection techniques studied extensively literature. Specifically, one can implement () best subset selection using function \(\texttt{regsubsets()}\) \(\textbf{leaps}\) package; (ii) forward/backward/stepwise selection using function \(\texttt{step()}\) R core; (iii) shrinkage methods including (adaptive) LASSO package; (iv) regularized ordinal regression model elastic net penalty package; (v) penalized regression models minimax concave penalty (MCP) smoothly clipped absolute deviation (SCAD) penalty package. dimension ultrahigh, sure independence screening method can applied package. variables grouped, one can apply group selection methods including group lasso, group MCP, group SCAD package. cases, \(\texttt{Step-0}\) may skipped experiment involves (small) set controlled variables. cases, controlled variables modeled regardless statistical significance predictive power. limit discussion focus goodness--fit analysis. \(\texttt{Step-1}\), can use diagnostic tools inspect model passed \(\texttt{Step-0}\), adjust functional form, add additional elements needed (e.g., higher-order interaction terms). categorical data, can use function \(\texttt{autoplot.resid()}\) package generate three types diagnostic plots: residual Q-Q plot, residual-vs-covariate plot, residual-vs-fitted plots. plots can used visualize discrepancy working model ``true’’ model. Similar plots can produced using function \(\texttt{diagnostic.plot()}\) package. diagnostic plots give practitioners insights refine model possibly transforming regression form adding higher-order terms. end diagnosing refining process, expect (\(\mathcal{M}_{full}\)) subsequent inferences including goodness--fit analysis. \(\texttt{Step-2}\), can use functions developed package examine goodness fit full model \(\mathcal{M}_{full}\) various reduced models interest. Specifically, can produce point interval estimates surrogate \(R^2\) using functions \(\texttt{surr_rsq()}\) \(\texttt{surr_rsq_ci()}\). addition, can quantify contribution individual variable overall surrogate \(R^2\) using function \(\texttt{surr_rsq_rank()}\). Based percentage contribution, function \(\texttt{surr_rsq_rank()}\) also provides ranks explanatory variables show relative importance. following section, show case study package can help us understand relative importance explanatory variables compare results across different samples. ``comparability’’ across different samples /models appealing feature surrogate \(R^2\), discussed detail along R implementation.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Xiaorui Zhu. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Zewei Lin. Author, contributor. Dungang Liu. Author, contributor. Brandon Greenwell. Author, contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Zhu X, Lin Z, Liu D, Greenwell B (2024). SurrogateRsq: Goodness--Fit Analysis Categorical Data using Surrogate R-Squared. R package version 0.2.1.9000, https://xiaorui.site/SurrogateRsq/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SurrogateRsq: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared},   author = {Xiaorui Zhu and Zewei Lin and Dungang Liu and Brandon Greenwell},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.2.1.9000},   url = {https://xiaorui.site/SurrogateRsq/}, }

title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
text: package implements tools goodness--fit analysis probit model (Dungang Liu, Xiaorui Zhu, Brandon Greenwell, Zewei Lin (2022)). package can generate point interval measure surrogate R2. can also provide ranking measure variable’s contribution terms surrogate goodness--fit measure. ranking assessment allows one check importance variable terms explained variance. can jointly used existing R packages variable selection model diagnostics model-building process.

title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
text: SurrogateRsq package available SurrogateRsq CRAN soon.

what: Install SurrogateRsq development version from GitHub (recommended)
title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
code: # Install the development version from GitHub if (!requireNamespace("devtools")) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("XiaoruiZhu/SurrogateRsq")

title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages("SurrogateRsq")

title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
text: following example shows R code analyzing white wine-tasting data ( data(“WhiteWine”) ).tasting dataset white wine contains 4898 samples 11 explanatory variables. explanatory variables physicochemical features wine, example, acidity, sugar, dioxide, pH, others. response variable tasting rating score wine, ranges 0 (bad) 10 (excellent).
code: library(SurrogateRsq) library(MASS) data("WhiteWine")  # Build the full model full_formula_white <-    as.formula(quality ~ fixed.acidity + volatile.acidity + citric.acid +                         residual.sugar + chlorides + free.sulfur.dioxide +                        total.sulfur.dioxide + density + pH + sulphates +                         alcohol)  naive_model_white <- polr(formula = full_formula_white,                            data    = WhiteWine,                            method  = "probit")  # selected model select_model_white <-    update(naive_model_white,           formula. =             ". ~ . - citric.acid - chlorides - total.sulfur.dioxide - density")  # surrogate R-squared surr_obj_white <-    surr_rsq(model      = select_model_white,            full_model = select_model_white,             avg.num    = 30)  print(surr_obj_white$surr_rsq,        digits = 3)        # surrogate R-squared rank table  Rank_table_white <-    surr_rsq_rank(object  = surr_obj_white,                  avg.num = 30)  print(Rank_table_white, digits = 3)  # 95% confidence interval surrogate R-squared  surr_obj_white_ci <- surr_rsq_ci(surr_rsq = surr_obj_white,                                 alpha     = 0.05,                                 B         = 2000)

what: A recommended workflow for categorical data modeling using SurrogateRsq and other statistical tools
title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
text: empirical studies, goodness--fit analysis used jointly statistical tools, variable screening/selection model diagnostics, model-building refining process. section, discuss follow workflow following diagram carry statistical modeling categorical data. also discuss use SurrogateRsq package existing R packages implement workflow. Liu et al. (2023)’s method requires full model, researchers practitioners can also follow process Figure initiate full model facilitate goodness--fit analysis. illustration workflow modeling categorical data Step-0, can use AIC/BIC/LASSO variable selection methods deemed appropriate trim prune set explanatory variables ``manageable’’ size (e.g., less 20). goal eliminate irrelevant variables researchers can better investigate model structure assessment. variable selection techniques studied extensively literature. Specifically, one can implement () best subset selection using function regsubsets() leaps package; (ii) forward/backward/stepwise selection using function step() R core; (iii) shrinkage methods including (adaptive) LASSO  package; (iv) regularized ordinal regression model elastic net penalty  package; (v) penalized regression models minimax concave penalty (MCP) smoothly clipped absolute deviation (SCAD) penalty  package. dimension ultrahigh, sure independence screening method can applied  package. variables grouped, one can apply group selection methods including group lasso, group MCP, group SCAD  package. cases, Step-0 may skipped experiment involves (small) set controlled variables. cases, controlled variables modeled regardless statistical significance predictive power. limit discussion focus goodness--fit analysis. Step-1, can use diagnostic tools inspect model passed Step-0, adjust functional form, add additional elements needed (e.g., higher-order interaction terms). categorical data, can use function autoplot.resid()  package generate three types diagnostic plots: residual Q-Q plot, residual-vs-covariate plot, residual-vs-fitted plots. plots can used visualize discrepancy working model ``true’’ model. Similar plots can produced using function diagnostic.plot()  package. diagnostic plots give practitioners insights refine model possibly transforming regression form adding higher-order terms. end diagnosing refining process, expect  (ℳfull) subsequent inferences including goodness--fit analysis. Step-2, can use functions developed  package examine goodness fit full model ℳfull various reduced models interest. Specifically, can produce point interval estimates surrogate R2 using functions surr_rsq() surr_rsq_ci(). addition, can quantify contribution individual variable overall surrogate R2 using function surr_rsq_rank(). Based percentage contribution, function surr_rsq_rank() also provides ranks explanatory variables show relative importance. following section, show case study package can help us understand relative importance explanatory variables compare results across different samples. ``comparability’’ across different samples /models appealing feature surrogate R2, discussed detail along R implementation.

what: A detailed example with other existing R packages for variable selection and model diagnostics
title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
code: # Load packages   library(SurrogateRsq) library(MASS)  # Load data and preparation   data("RedWine") data("WhiteWine")  ### We remove an outlier where total.sulfur.dioxide>200. RedWine2 <- subset(RedWine, total.sulfur.dioxide <= 200)

previous_headings: A detailed example with other existing R packages for variable selection and model diagnostics
what: Initiating a full model using variable selection and model diagnostics
title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
code: full_formula <-    as.formula(quality ~ fixed.acidity + volatile.acidity + citric.acid +                 residual.sugar + chlorides + free.sulfur.dioxide +                total.sulfur.dioxide + density + pH + sulphates +                 alcohol)  naive_model <- polr(formula = full_formula,                      data    = RedWine2,                      method  = "probit") summary(naive_model)  # Use exhuastive search for searching the best model  fullmodel <- polr(quality ~ ., data = RedWine2, method = "probit") model_exhau <- leaps::regsubsets(x     = quality ~ .,                                   data  = RedWine2,                                   nbest = 2,                                   nvmax = 11) plot(model_exhau)  select_model <-    update(naive_model,           formula. =             ". ~ . - fixed.acidity - citric.acid - residual.sugar - density")   # Conduct model diagnostics by following the workflow  library(PAsso) p_sulphates <-    diagnostic.plot(object    = select_model,                    output    = "covariate",                    x         = RedWine2$sulphates,                    xlab      = "(a)")  mod_add_square <-    update(select_model, formula. = ". ~ . + I(sulphates^2)")  p_sulphates2 <-    diagnostic.plot(object    = mod_add_square,                    output    = "covariate",                    x         = RedWine2$sulphates,                    xlab      = "(b)")  mod_full <-    update(mod_add_square, formula. = ". ~ . + I(sulphates^3)")  p_sulphates3 <-    diagnostic.plot(object    = mod_full,                    output    = "covariate",                    x         = RedWine2$sulphates,                    xlab      = "(c)")  gridExtra::grid.arrange(p_sulphates, p_sulphates2, p_sulphates3, ncol = 3)  # Compare models  library(stargazer) stargazer(naive_model, select_model, mod_add_square, mod_full,            column.labels = c("Naive", "Selected", "+ sulphates-squared", "+ sulphates-cubic"),           order = c("fixed.acidity", "volatile.acidity", "citric.acid",                     "residual.sugar", "chlorides", "free.sulfur.dioxide",                     "total.sulfur.dioxide", "density", "pH",                      "sulphates", "I(sulphates-sqr)", "I(sulphates-cubic)",                     "alcohol"),           type = "text")

previous_headings: A detailed example with other existing R packages for variable selection and model diagnostics
what: Goodness-of-fit analysis and its extended utility
title: Goodness-of-Fit Analysis for Categorical Data using the Surrogate R-Squared
code: library(SurrogateRsq) set.seed(777)  surr_obj_mod_full <-    surr_rsq(model      = mod_full,            full_model = mod_full,             avg.num    = 30) print(surr_obj_mod_full$surr_rsq,        digits = 3)  # Surrogate R-squared of a smaller model (select_model)  surr_obj_lm <- surr_rsq(model   = select_model,                          full_model = mod_full,                          avg.num    = 30)  print(surr_obj_lm$surr_rsq,        digit = 3)   # Construct the confidence interval   full_mod_rsq_ci <-    surr_rsq_ci(surr_rsq = surr_obj_mod_full,               alpha    = 0.05,               B        = 2000) full_mod_rsq_ci   # Creat the importance ranking table   set.seed(777) # Importance ranking table of the full model Rank_table_mod_full <-    surr_rsq_rank(object  = surr_obj_mod_full,                  avg.num = 30) print(Rank_table_mod_full, digits = 3)  # Importance ranking table of two groups of variables var_set <- list(c("sulphates", "I(sulphates^2)", "I(sulphates^3)"),                 c("I(sulphates^2)", "I(sulphates^3)"))  Rank_table2 <-    surr_rsq_rank(object  = surr_obj_mod_full,                  var.set = var_set,                  avg.num = 30) print(Rank_table2, digits = 3)

what: Red wine quality dataset of the Portuguese
title: Red wine quality dataset of the Portuguese
text: red wine tasting preference data used study Cortez, Cerdeira, Almeida, Matos, Reis 2009. red wine contains 1599 samples 12 variables including tasting preference score red wine physicochemical characteristics.

title: Red wine quality dataset of the Portuguese
code: data(RedWine)

title: Red wine quality dataset of the Portuguese
text: data frame 1599 rows, quality score, 11 variables physicochemical properties wines. quality Tasting preference rating score provided minimum three sensory ordinal values 0 (bad) 10 (excellent). final sensory score median evaluations. fixed.acidity fixed acidity physicochemical property unit (g(tartaric acid)/dm^3). volatile.acidity volatile acidity unit g(acetic acid)/dm^3. citric.acid citric acidity unit g/dm^3. residual.sugar residual sugar unit g/dm^3. chlorides chlorides unit g(sodium chloride)/dm^3. free.sulfur.dioxide free sulfur dioxide unit mg/dm^3. total.sulfur.dioxide total sulfur dioxide unit mg/dm^3. density density unit g/cm^3. pH wine's pH value. sulphates sulphates unit g(potassium sulphates)/dm^3. alcohol alcohol unit \

title: Red wine quality dataset of the Portuguese
text: Cortez, P., Cerdeira, ., Almeida, F., Matos, T., Reis, J. (2009), “Modeling wine preferences data mining physicochemical properties,” Decision Support Systems, 47, 547–553. doi:10.1016/j.dss.2009.05.016

what: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
title: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
text: can provide surrogate R-squared user specified model. function generate S3 object surrogate R-squared measure called functions package. generic S3 function print also developed present surrogate R-squared measure.

title: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
code: surr_rsq(model, full_model, avg.num = 30, asym = FALSE, newdata = NULL, ...)

title: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
text: model reduced model needs investigated. reported surrogate R-squared reduced model. full_model full model contains predictors data set. model object also contain dataset fitting full model reduced model first argument. avg.num number replication averaging surrogate R-squared. asym logical argument whether use asymptotic version surrogate R-squared. details paper Liu et al. (2023). ... Additional optional arguments.

title: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
text: object class "surr_rsq" list containing following components: surr_rsq surrogate R-squared value; reduced_model reduced model investigation. subset full model; full_model full model used generating surrogate response. passed initial variable screening model diagnostics (see Paper reference); data dataset contains response variable predictors.

title: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
text: Zhu, X., Liu, D., Lin, Z., Greenwell, B. (2022). SurrogateRsq: R package categorical data goodness--fit analysis using surrogate R-squared Liu, D., Zhu, X., Greenwell, B., & Lin, Z. (2023). new goodness‐‐fit measure probit models: Surrogate R2. British Journal Mathematical Statistical Psychology, 76(1), 192-210.

title: A function to calculate the surrogate R-squared measure. — surr_rsq
code: data("RedWine")  full_formula <- as.formula(quality ~ fixed.acidity + volatile.acidity + citric.acid+ residual.sugar + chlorides + free.sulfur.dioxide + total.sulfur.dioxide + density + pH + sulphates + alcohol)  full_mod <- polr(formula = full_formula, data=RedWine, method  = "probit")  select_model <- update(full_mod, formula. = ". ~ . - fixed.acidity - citric.acid - residual.sugar - density") surr_obj_sele_mod <- surr_rsq(model = select_model, full_model = full_mod,                                data = RedWine, avg.num = 30) print(surr_obj_sele_mod$surr_rsq, digits = 3) #> [1] 0.41

what: A function to calculate the interval estimate of the surrogate R-squared measure — surr_rsq_ci
title: A function to calculate the interval estimate of the surrogate R-squared measure — surr_rsq_ci
text: function generates interval measure surrogate R-squared bootstrap.

title: A function to calculate the interval estimate of the surrogate R-squared measure — surr_rsq_ci
code: surr_rsq_ci(   object,   alpha = 0.05,   B = 2000,   asym = FALSE,   parallel = FALSE,   ... )

title: A function to calculate the interval estimate of the surrogate R-squared measure — surr_rsq_ci
text: object object class "surr_rsq" generated function "surr_rsq". contains following components: surr_rsq, reduced_model, full_model, data. alpha significance level alpha. confidence level 1-alpha. B number bootstrap replications. asym logical argument whether use asymptotic version surrogate R-squared. details paper Liu et al. (2023). parallel logical argument whether conduct parallel bootstrapping surrogate R-squared construct interval estimate. clusters need registered registerDoParallel(cl) beforehand. ... Additional optional arguments.

title: A function to calculate the interval estimate of the surrogate R-squared measure — surr_rsq_ci
text: list contains CI_lower, CI_upper.

title: A function to calculate the interval estimate of the surrogate R-squared measure — surr_rsq_ci
code: data("RedWine")  full_formula <- as.formula(quality ~ fixed.acidity + volatile.acidity + citric.acid + residual.sugar + chlorides + free.sulfur.dioxide + total.sulfur.dioxide + density + pH + sulphates + alcohol)  fullmodel <- polr(formula = full_formula,data=RedWine, method  = "probit")  select_model <- update(fullmodel, formula. = ". ~ . - fixed.acidity - citric.acid - residual.sugar - density")  surr_rsq_select <- surr_rsq(select_model, fullmodel, data = RedWine, avg.num = 30)  # surr_rsq_ci(surr_rsq_select, alpha = 0.05, B = 2000, parallel = FALSE) # Not run, it takes time.  # surr_rsq_ci(surr_rsq_select, alpha = 0.05, B = 2000, parallel = TRUE) # Not run, it takes time.

what: The contribution of each variable in the final model — surr_rsq_rank
title: The contribution of each variable in the final model — surr_rsq_rank
text: function calculates reduction surrogate R-squared goodness--fit variable measure relative explanatory power. function creates table containing reductions surrogate R-squared removing one variables model.

title: The contribution of each variable in the final model — surr_rsq_rank
code: surr_rsq_rank(object, avg.num = 30, var.set = NA, ...)

title: The contribution of each variable in the final model — surr_rsq_rank
text: object object class "surr_rsq" generated function "surr_rsq". contains following components: surr_rsq, reduced_model, full_model, data. avg.num number replication averaging surrogate R-square. var.set list contains sets. component sets represents variables want examine contribution goodness fit. , one component list, model fit removing specified variables. ... Additional optional arguments.

title: The contribution of each variable in the final model — surr_rsq_rank
text: default return list contains contribution Surrogate R-squared variable full_model. var.set specified, return list contribution groups variables var.set.

title: The contribution of each variable in the final model — surr_rsq_rank
code: data("WhiteWine")  sele_formula <- as.formula(quality ~ fixed.acidity + volatile.acidity +                           residual.sugar +  + free.sulfur.dioxide +                           pH + sulphates + alcohol)  sele_mod <- polr(formula = sele_formula,               data = WhiteWine,               method = "probit")  sur1 <- surr_rsq(model = sele_mod,               full_model = sele_mod,               avg.num = 100) # \donttest{ rank_tab_sur1 <- surr_rsq_rank(object  = sur1,                                avg.num = 30) print(rank_tab_sur1) #>     Removed Variable SurrogateRsq Reduction Contribution Ranking #>              alcohol      0.07042   0.23733       77.12%       1 #>     volatile.acidity      0.24411   0.06364       20.68%       2 #>       residual.sugar      0.28971   0.01804        5.86%       3 #>  free.sulfur.dioxide      0.30312   0.00463        1.50%       4 #>            sulphates      0.30422   0.00354        1.15%       5 #>        fixed.acidity      0.30479   0.00296        0.96%       6 #>                   pH      0.30717   0.00058        0.19%       7 #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------  #> The total surrogate R-squared of the full model is:  #> [1] 0.30775 # }

title: SurrogateRsq 0.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-04-24

title: SurrogateRsq 0.2.1
text: data argument removed three main functions surr_rsq(), surr_rsq_ci(), surr_rsq_rank(). dataset directly pulled full_model object. bug related bootstrapped data model updating steps surr_rsq_ci() fixed (#2, #3). rsq() function removed since needed.

title: SurrogateRsq 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-02-15

title: Changes in version 0.1.1
text: package supports ordinal logistic regression models.

title: Changes in version 0.1.1
text: “print()” surr_rsq, print() summary() functions needed surr_rsq_ci surr_rsq_rank. …

title: SurrogateRsq 0.1.0
text: package four main functions: rsq, surr_rsq, surr_rsq_ci, surr_rsq_rank. surr_rsq() function producing point estimate surrogate R-squared user-specified model. surr_rsq_ci() function generating interval measure surrogate R-squared designated confidence level. surr_rsq_rank() function produce ranking explanatory variables based contributions overall surrogate R-squared. rsq() function produce pseudo R-squared measures literature.
